newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch police thwart second Hague arson attack.
newsitem.headline: Dutch police thwart second Hague arson attack.

text.p: Police said on Tuesday they had thwarted an arson attack on the home of one of the organisers of a march held to protest against an earlier fire-bombing which killed six members of a Turkish immigrant family last week.

Police in The Hague broke down the door to the 56-year-old man's apartment early on Tuesday morning and put out a fire in the hall. The man was badly shaken by the attack but was otherwise unharmed, they said.

Anonymous pamphlets distributed in the neighbourhood earlier had threatened those who organised and took part in a march to protest against last week's attack in which a Turkish mother and five of her children were burned to death in their home.
A 30-strong police team is investigating the case and authorities have not yet concluded that the arson attacks were racially motivated.
But Prime Minister Wim Kok said on Thursday that even the suspicion of a racist attack was worrying.
"The thought that we could be dealing with arson with some ethnic intention is dramatic. That would be an entirely new phenomenon in the Netherlands and a serious signal," he said.
The attacks have been widely condemned and Friday's protest march in The Hague drew 3,000 people including the city's mayor and foreign aid minister Jan Pronk.

The Netherlands prides itself on a reputation for racial tolerance and overtly anti-immigrant political parties have received less support here than in neighbouring countries such as France, Germany and Belgium.
